title: The Mountain Between Me and My Past

content: I stood at the top of the mountain in downtown Taormina, Sicily, debating how to get back to my hotel. I had just run into some friends who told me they had walked here, indicating walking as a legitimate means of transportation. It was well over 90 degrees, and I had multiple shopping bags, but time was on my side, and I was always looking for an adventure. Google maps said the nearest train was a 19-minute walk, so do I do a €5 train ride or a €50 taxi ride? The answer was obvious; I began walking toward the train. AirPods in, Lorde’s new album playing, my recent retail therapy, and the beautiful Italian coast set the perfect vibe. About five minutes in I realized what I thought was a “walk” was actually a hike down the mountain on a secluded path. Sure, there were some stairs and a relatively paved walkway, but it was narrow with many turns and, overall, not much stability. Most people would’ve turned around. When my mom hears this, she will probably scold me. But instead of turning around, I kept going. By the time I made it to the bottom, my foot was bleeding from blisters, and I was dripping sweat. I arrived at the train station, panting, legs shaking, and arms burning. I looked for a bench to sit on and found a single seat in between a few families with younger children. I smiled at the group and plopped down right in the middle of them. My body didn’t really have a choice but to sit down at that point. After striking up a conversation with the parents, I realized most had either opted to take a cab down the mountain or a cable car. After confessing that I hiked down, I felt ridiculous. Of course, I didn’t know that a cable car was an option. And yes, I could technically afford the taxi, but saving €50 was a much better option. But still, I chose to do an objectively tough hike down a mountain in the heat, without proper shoes, and carrying multiple shopping bags. Why? Perhaps the reason was almost as ridiculous as the hike was. Maybe I just wanted to prove that I could do it. To show to myself that my MS doesn’t get in the way of my independence. It feels like ever since I failed the neurological exam during my second flare, I have been chasing after a feeling. It was during my second hospitalization; a neurology resident was conducting a physical exam to test my muscle strength. The resident would lightly push my legs down with her hands, and it was my job to stop her from succeeding. To my complete shock and horror, I was too weak to stop her from pushing my legs down. I made her try multiple times until I could believe what was happening right in front of me. Nearly three years later, I still find myself chasing the feeling that, despite my MS, I am not weak.

content: I think I hiked down that mountain out of pure stubbornness. I wanted to get down there and make my way to my hotel on my own; without having to give in to an overpriced taxi ride. I wanted to be independent and to travel strategically. And most importantly, I wanted to prove to my MS that I am strong enough to hike down a mountain. What, like it’s hard? I wanted to put so much distance between me and the girl that was too weak to pass her physical exam that day in the hospital. A mountain’s worth of distance.

After continuing my conversation with the parents — and battling an inner existential crisis — I explained my travel plans. “You are having too much fun!” one of the dads said. I laughed it off. What was wrong with having too much fun? Is anything ever “too much” fun? Most people don’t realize the hardships I had to overcome in order to get to the part in my life where I can have “too much fun.” Perhaps the fun and independence I am chasing is an attempt to outweigh the pain of the past. You must remember, there was a time in my life when my MS made it hard to simply walk or stand up straight.

content: But upon reflection, both my actions (hiking down a mountain unprepared) and the concept of “having too much fun” stem from a scarcity mindset. Let me elaborate. I am afraid that if I do not hike down this mountain today, maybe a flare will hit me tomorrow and that would have been my last opportunity to use my legs properly. I am afraid that if I do not capitalize on “fun” today, the dark days of my MS could come back and take my joy away. Both of these mindsets stem from a place of lack and fear. And most importantly, neither allow you to truly live in the present.

I probably need to introduce some corrective exercises into my life. It is OK to feel proud of myself for getting to a place where I can accomplish a hike down a mountain. It took years, pain, and lots of determination to get here. BUT I have nothing to prove. Instead of forcing myself down a mountain just to prove a point, I could have chosen to go easy on my body. If I had looked around for a bit longer, I probably would have discovered the cable car! With an abundance mindset, I would have explored a third option instead of limiting myself to two objectively bad options (a hike and an overpriced taxi ride).

content: And as for having too much fun, maybe that is just a side effect of being in my mid-20s. I do not think I need to cut myself off from the traveling, partying, and socializing, but introducing balance is an important life skill. Knowing I can say no to an event because there will be an abundance of more in the future will put me in a better state of homeostasis.

How wonderful that my trip down a mountain in Italy has provided me with such clarity into the way I am operating. I feel lucky and proud to be at a place of open self-reflection. Especially approaching my 27th birthday and my third year of MS, it is important to try to embrace my life with chronic illness from a place of abundance and not scarcity. The tough days may come, regardless of whether I was anxiously waiting for them or not. I might as well live in the present, practice gratitude, and have “too much fun.”
